results.title: Raining stones
results.creator_credit: Ken Loach, Sally Hibbin, Film Four International and Parallax Pictures
results.brief_description: Set on a council estate in Middleton on the outskirts of Manchester, “Raining Stones” is an uncompromising look at England’s poorest citizens in a country where unemployment has created an alienated underclass and bred petty crime, vandalism, drug abuse and poverty. Already barely making ends meet, Bob supports his family by doing odd jobs. When his only asset, his van, is stolen, the family’s prospects become even grimmer. Now unemployed he is still determined to find the money to buy a new communion dress for his daughter’s first communion - even if it means turning to crime. Without ever mentioning politics, Loach makes a powerful and effective political statement about the way economic policies destroy social coherence. (Awards: Winner of the Special Jury Prize, Cannes Film Festival, 1993)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Loach, Sally Hibbin, Film Four International and Parallax Pictures

results.title: Thirty two short films about Glenn Gould
results.creator_credit: Francois Girard, Niv Fichman and Rhombus Media
results.brief_description: Thirty two short films about Glenn Gould is an inventive and playful film that seeks to portray the genius, complex and eccentric personality of legendary pianist, Glenn Gould. The film borrows its structure from JS Bach’s Goldberg Variations (and name from Beethoven’s “32 variations in C Minor”), and juxtaposes 32 short vignettes to portray the broadly influenced Gould. The film uses a combination of interview, dramatisation and animation, punctuated with the music of Gould’s live performances (mostly Bach, Beethoven and Shoenberg) to humorously fill the portrait of Gould. Included is an excerpt from Norman McLaren’s experimental animation ‘Spheres’ and Gould’s live radio broadcast of 28th December 1967, ‘The Idea of North’. Peppered throughout are Gould’s philosophical ruminations such as, “for every hour you spend with people you need x more hours on your own”.

results.title: Masque of the red death
results.creator_credit: Roger Corman, George Willoughby and Alta Vista Productions
results.brief_description: On a mist-shrouded hill, an old woman crosses paths with a masked stranger in red, who gives her a rose and promises that the villages’ day of deliverance from the sadistic Prince Prospero is at hand. The Satan-worshipping Prospero (Vincent Price) blackmails the virtuous Francesca (Jane Asher) into coming to his castle in order to to save the lives of her fiancee and his father. Francesca recoils from the debauched decadence of the devil-worshipping nobles seeking sanctuary from the red death, and encounters Lady Juliana, who aspires to be the bride of Satan. In classical horror film fashion, Francesca spends much of her time prowling the baroque corridors of Prospero’s abode at midnight, stumbling upon Satanic rituals and being frightened by eerie noises. Eager to remove her rival from the castle, Juliana assists Francesca to escape, but unfortunately, Prospero is one step ahead of them, and detains Francesca again. Ashamed of leaving her in Prospero’s tainted hands, Gino attempts a rescue effort, but is stopped by the mysterious stranger in red, who offers to help as long as Gino does not attempt to enter the castle. The stranger confronts Prospero - who mistakes him for Satan - and all hell breaks loose as his identity is exposed. An atmospheric piece of gothic horror from the king of low-budget cult cinema, Roger Corman, loosely adapted from a story by Edgar Allen Poe.

results.title: The Last temptation of Christ [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina, Cineplex Odeon and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: A controversial and challenging film of Jesus Christ’s life. Based on the novel by Nikos Kazantzakis, this Christ is an anguished, vain, sensual man battling the forces of both good and evil. The film traces the conflicts that lead to his final disavowal of the flesh in favour of the life of the son of God. Scorsese had for years tried to film the Kazantzakis’ novel and on its release it was met with great debate and fury. The film, however, is deeply spiritual. With Willem Dafoe as Jesus, Barbara Hershey as Mary Magdalene, Harvey Keitel as Judas, and an impressive cameo by David Bowie as Pontius Pilate. Music by Peter Gabriel.

results.title: La Bamba
results.creator_credit: Luis Valdez, Taylor Hackford, Columbia and New Visions Pictures
results.brief_description: Musical biography of Ritchie Valens, a poor Mexican-American who became a rock’n’roll sensation at age 17 in the 1950’s. Lou Diamond Phillips portrays Valens whose musical career ended when he was killed in the plane crash that also claimed the life of Buddy Holly. The music of Valens is performed by Los Lobos on the soundtrack.

results.title: A Very sheepish affair
results.creator_credit: Joseph E. Levine, Robert Maxwell, Anroste Films and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 37 of Series “Dodo, the kid from outer space”
Professor Fingers has invented a new sheep shearing machine that gives a really close shave. Unfortunately he tests it in the middle of zero degrees temperatures and the sheep are suffering. Dodo steps in to help the Professor make amends.

results.title: Samson and Delilah
results.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Cecil B. De Mille’s famous epic style is highlighted in this classic bible story about the legendary strongman Samson and the temptress Delilah, who helped destroy him. Lauded for its lush cinematography, performances, costumes, sets and special effects, it was a box office smash.

constellations_other.name: Swords, sandals and lightning bolts
constellations_other.description: In Thor: Love and Thunder, Russell Crowe plays one of the most recogniseable gods in the pantheon – Zeus. His scenes lampoon his Oscar-winning role in Gladiator, one of the most recognised films in a classic genre.

constellations_other.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_other.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

results.description: Cecil B. De Mille’s famous epic style is highlighted in this classic Bible story about the legendary strongman Samson, and the temptress Delilah, who seduced, betrayed and helped to destroy him. Victor Mature is the classic Samson; strong, brave and fearless as he wrestles lions and Philistines bare-handed. Hedy Lamarr is stunning as Delilah; in an array of dazzling and seductive costumes. Action packed, this Biblical epic is a spectacle to enjoy. Also stars George Sanders and Angela Lansbury.
description_for_label: Cecil B. De Mille’s famous epic style is highlighted in this classic Bible story about the legendary strongman Samson, and the temptress Delilah, who seduced, betrayed and helped to destroy him. Victor Mature is the classic Samson; strong, brave and fearless as he wrestles lions and Philistines bare-handed. Hedy Lamarr is stunning as Delilah; in an array of dazzling and seductive costumes. Action packed, this Biblical epic is a spectacle to enjoy. Also stars George Sanders and Angela Lansbury.

results.title: DoDo and the space pirates
results.creator_credit: John Halas, Joy Batchelor, Joseph E. Levine, Robert Maxwell, Anroste Films and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 30 of Series “DoDo: the kid from outer space”.
DoDo is a kid with extraordinary powers, and he knows how to use them. When he arrives on earth, DoDo has a series of adventures with Compy the Computer Bird and Professor Fingers, who can invent anything. From Hollywood to Loch Ness, from the Pyramids to Paris, DoDo and his pals have fun at the movies, help Interpol capture some spies, find sunken treasure, visit a rodeo and still have time to keep the world from being sold. In this episode DoDo is called in to avert trouble from a UFO which he manages to achieve in a non-violent fashion. Animated by Harold Whitaker, John Smith, Tony Whitehouse, Tony Guy, Bruno Bozzetto, Arthur Humberstone.

results.title: Wing Chun
results.brief_description: Inspired by an historical figure, “Wing Chun” is a martial arts film with an unusual feminist sway. It is 19th Century China, and a group of bandits attacks a remote Chinese village in an attempt to kidnap a beautiful young widow, Charmy. Their plans are disrupted, however, by Yim Wing Chun, a local bean-curd shop owner who also happens to be a master fighter. She defeats the bandits single-handedly, thus infuriating their leader who comes back to the town with a vengeance. The plot thickens with the return of Wing Chun’s childhood sweetheart, now also a martial arts master, who returns after a very long absence. He soon falls for Charmy, mistaking her for Wing Chun while at the same time taking Wing Chun for a man. What ensues are some comical manoeuvring and astounding fight sequences which culminate in the final showdown between Wing Chun and the bandits. Cast includes: Michelle Yeoh, Donnie Yen and Tsui Siu Keung. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: Bedrooms and hallways [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Rose Troche, Ceci Dempsey, Dorothy Berwin and Berwin and Dempsey Productions
results.brief_description: Rose Troche’s (“Go Fish”) second feature film is a gentle and amusing study into the nuances of sexual preference, dating and masculinity. Using Leo’s (Kevin McKidd) 30th birthday bash as a basis, the film traces Leo’s relationship to the guests; gay room mate Darren (Tom Hollander) and his real estate agent boyfriend (Hugo Weaving) with a penchant for using the bedrooms of the houses he’s selling for their trysts; straight and single friend Angie (Julie Graham); new Age guru and leader of Leo’s men’s group, Keith (Simon Callow); Leo’s previous boyfriend, Brendan (James Purefoy) and Brendan’s current girlfriend, Sally (Jennifer Ehle), who also happens to be Leo’s high school sweetheart. Central to the film are the gatherings of the men’s group for masculine assertiveness and when Leo admits his attraction to seemingly straight, Irishman Brendan, it opens the floodgates for other members of the group with surprising results. (Awards: Winner Audience Award, London Film Festival, 1998)
